<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_EndTest:
```c
void UtAssert_EndTest(void)
{
    uint32                 Ct;
    bool                   SegmentValid;
    UtAssert_TestCounter_t Local_SegmentCounters;
    char                   Local_SegmentName[sizeof(CurrentSegment)];

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    SegmentValid = (UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases > 0);
    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        ++UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_SegmentCounters.TestSegmentCount = UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_TotalCounters.TotalTestCases += UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;
        for (Ct = 0; Ct < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX; ++Ct)
        {
            UT_TotalCounters.CaseCount[Ct] += UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[Ct];
        }
        memcpy(&Local_SegmentCounters, &UT_SegmentCounters, sizeof(Local_SegmentCounters));

        /*
         * note, strcpy is OK because both are fixed size buffers of the same size,
         * and the null termination on CurrentSegment was locally enforced already
         */
        strcpy(Local_SegmentName, CurrentSegment);
    }

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(Local_SegmentName, &Local_SegmentCounters);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, "No test cases\n");
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the above fragments either use functions from <string.h> (memcpy, strcpy, memset) or define a buffer whose size is derived from sizeof(CurrentSegment) and therefore could lead to out-of-bounds accesses when used with those functions. All other lines in the function are control flow, lock/unlock calls, arithmetic updates, loop iterations, or function calls that do not invoke <string.h> string/ memory functions and thus are outside the scope of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The comment asserting safety for strcpy does not eliminate the need to inspect the strcpy usage and the related buffer declaration and sizes — those are included above for investigation.
